Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative proposal: ABI Sustaining: The Environmental-Data Automated Track Annotation (Env-DATA) system
Award.AbstractNarration:
How an animal moves through their environment reveals much about their ecology and how they respond to modern changes to the planet such as development and climate change. GPS technology embedded in collars (mammal) or backpacks (birds) has revolutionized the ability to track animals, providing more detail than ever before, sometimes in real-time. However, to make the most of these new tracking data they must be seen in the context of the world through which the animals are moving by linking their tracks to remote sensing maps showing weather and ecosystem. With both the animal and environmental data growing rapidly, there are increasing technical challenges and knowledge gaps that inhibit the widespread application of linking these types of datasets for movement ecology research. The Environmental-Data Automated Track Annotation system (Env-DATA) is a web-based tool to give direct access for movement ecology researchers to thousands of environmental datasets. It provides intuitive and easy to use graphic user interface-based access to these datasets. Env-DATA is hosted by and interfaces with Movebank, a global movement data archive, open to the broad public worldwide. Env-DATA is open and accessible to anyone. It provides easy access to already public datasets, as well and some datasets that are not otherwise open. Env-DATA provides users with tools to publish the combined environmental data along with the animal track it was used to annotate in the Movebank Data Depository. Published data sets are allocated a DOI and can be accessed and searched as electronic publications, provided an agreement from the owner of the track data. Annual workshops at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences will reach out to new users within academia, government, and public organizations that track animals.

Env-DATA is at the cutting edge of the "contextual revolution" in movement ecology where combining analysis of movement patterns and incorporating the environmental background of the movement has become a necessary component for understanding and modeling animal movement. By providing intuitive and easy to use access to an unprecedented number of environmental datasets and variables, Env-DATA enables animal movement researchers to overcome technical challenges and knowledge gaps, and to fully utilize globally available environmental information. Env-DATA links movement tracks with environmental data from different remote-sensing and global reanalysis data providers, including NASA, NOAA, and ECMWF. Env-DATA interprets environmental variables in the correct encryption, grid, and projection systems and interpolates the data in space and time to the observed animal track locations, or a collection of comparison points or grid. Funding through this proposal will allow support of continuous on-going operations of Env-DATA, which requires regular quality control tests to detect cases where the data providers to Env-DATA may have changed the metadata, location, or access protocol. In these cases, technical support to update the system is necessary. It also requires regular availability of a user-support "help-desk". Outreach and training of new and existing users, as well as collecting first-hand feedback from users will be conducted by annual user workshops. All talks and tutorials in the workshop will be filmed and posted to the workshop website and on YouTube. Env-DATA PIs, staff, and researchers using Env-DATA will provide lectures to the broad public in the NC Museum. Undergraduate students will assist in workshop coordination and Env-DATA user support. To access Env-DATA and Movebank, visit https://www.movebank.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Movement ecology is a growing field that uses patterns of animal movement to understand their ecology, interactions with the environment, response to land use change and climate change, and to better manage and conserve animal species. A key tool for animal movement research is the movement track, and its environmental context. Advances in technology have dramatically improved the tracking data that can be collected, especially by miniaturized GPS tags, leading to new opportunities for discovery, but also new challenges in data management. In parallel, data on the environmental context of these movements has also expanded, with data coming from remote sensing, ground observations, and weather and ecosystem reanalysis models.  However, technical challenges and knowledge gaps inhibit the widespread application of many environmental datasets in movement ecology research.  Movebank (www.movebank.org) is an international database for animal movement observations. It has thousands of users that report movement data from hundreds of species. Movebank now includes billions of reported animal locations, observed with various methods, including GPS tags, radio telemetry, light-based geolocators, and bird rings.  Env-DATA is a library of tools within Movebank that automate the retrieval and interpolation of environmental data to support animal movement research. Using Env-DATA, users with animal movement data can access, download and process remote sensing data from NASA, weather reanalysis data from the American NCEP and European ECMWF services, and many other model-based or remote sensing based datasets. Over the project period, hundreds of Env-DATA users have downloaded terabytes of supporting environmental data for movement research. As environmental data providers improve and update the datasets they offer and their accessibility, a constant challenge for Env-DATA is to maintain access to these datasets, and provide access to new and useful datasets.

Intellectual merits: During the project we continuously updated Env-DATA to maintain access to linked data products as NASA, NOAA, ECMWF and other providers changed product versions, access protocol and metadata. We have linked numerous new datasets, including vegetation and ocean data from the VIIRS instrument on board the Suomi NPP satellite that replaces NASA?s MODIS products, OSCAR ocean currents datasets, precipitation data from the Global Precipitation Mission (GPM), and snow and ice data from NASA-MODIS. We have conducted many in-person and web-based user training sessions for researchers and professionals in using Movebank and Env-DATA. We have answered hundreds of questions by email and phone, maintained an online user manual, and created and posted an on-line workshop with lectures, tutorials and scripts.

Broader impacts: We conducted four workshops in three countries with 98 participants to expand the user base of Env-DATA and improve access to environmental data by animal movement researchers and conservation managers. The workshops were recorded and can be found on-line (https://movebankworkshopraleighnc.netlify.app/), where the recorded lectures have received over 5000 views.

We developed a comprehensive data policy and implemented data licenses and embargo options for tracking data in Movebank to improve their persistence and accessibility, increasing the amount of data publicly available to use with EnvDATA. During the project period we worked with our users to publish 336 studies in the Movebank Data Repository, each with a Creative Commons Zero public domain license and associated study in Movebank, providing data that can be used by anyone with Env-DATA.

We collaborated with animal movement researchers interested in the Arctic region to create a public Arctic Animal Movement Archive (AAMA). This thematic archive collects millions of movement locations, of multiple species from hundreds of studies over the last decades. It allows researchers and wildlife managers to access movement data over long periods, large areas and multiple species, a task that was typically impossible for any single user as the data were owned by many disparate individuals and institutions and were rarely shared before the archive creation.

We established new partnerships between Movebank and end user organization that manage and research wildlife. These include Birds Canada, EURING, the Migratory Connectivity Project, the National Audubon Society, the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute, and Wyoming Game and Fish Department. In each case we are providing a platform for these groups to connect with Movebank users and store, share and access animal tracking data for input to public outreach and conservation products and tools they are developing.
